Shape: A large, long-tailed sparrow. When perched, it often looks long-bodied with a thin neck and a round head. The tail is long and rounded.
Compared Size: Larger than an American Goldfinch, smaller than a Western Meadowlark.

description: Adults have a bold, blocky facial pattern that sets them apart from other sparrows. Chestnut and white stripes streak across the head, a black mustache runs down the sides of the throat, and the cheeks have chestnut spots. The outer tail feathers are tipped in white and a black spot marks the center of the chest. Juveniles have a ghosting of the adult's facial pattern and heavy streaking on the breast and flanks.
Usually feeds on the ground for seed and insects. Flies into trees and shrubs when disturbed. During the breeding season, males sing from elevated perches.
Found in grasslands, roadsides, farmlands, pastures, and open country with scattered trees and shrubs.
